blockchain technology at the base has a distributed ledger that everybody owns copy of a consensus mechanism so that

engine on top and we think about block chains we think about it the interface that developers are using is building

chained set of blocks each and this is how it kind of becomes cryptographically immutable is each blocks has set of

basically you can go and make sure that if somebody tampers with a block of transactions and say says you know for
like a financial point of view like say I owe somebody a hundred bucks I can go
through and quickly see that something has been tampered with a key difference between a ledger database and a
blotching Network though is that every single organization in the blockchain network has their own copy of this data
and that is pretty important because it kind of enables everybody to be on the
same playing field versus if I had a database and say expose that data to you if I say cut off your access or deleted
the database you would lose access to that you wouldn't really be in control of your own destiny so that's a key difference between we're talking about
centralized Ledger's and blockchain is that every entity and a blockchain network has a copy of that data same

in your bank account your application probably cares more about what's the state of it but if you had to go back in time and trace all the state changes
that happen for a key you can do that through the journal and that's that immutable state change database that you

do incredibly poor performance and takes a lot of energy but you have to use

for networks though that say you know everybody in like say a consortium of banks

some of them don't fabric does and actually has two ways that you can limit who can see what transaction so the kind
of more brute-force ways fabric utilizes what's called a channel and a channel is a kind of shared sub ledger among a set
of people that are on the network now it could be one-to-one it could be that everybody in the network is on the same channel that means that everyone is
access to all the chain code and ledger data on that channel but it might be
that out of the ten people on the network five of them are on channel a five of them are channel B in some set
are in channel C and you can create these sub ledgers to limit which folks
in the network can see or access that specific channel and there's a variety of commands to create these channels and
bite people to them people in the channel can vote on certain things and that's one way to limit who can see what
in a fabric Network there's also another feature called private data in a fabric network which is kind of scopes it down to even sub
channel level and and how that works is basically if I do a transaction with another party I can make it so that only
those two people can see the context of really what that transaction was and on
the actual ledger to everybody else in that channel you see some evidence that something happened but you don't really
know what it was and who was between now for some use cases you don't even want that in fabric today doesn't
support that to my knowledge but in many cases it's fine to just obscure what's going on and actually even more useful
because both of those parties can go back to a ledger that's maintained by a
set of people that's more than just those two people to maintain that this thing happens so that kind of allows you
to use the channel as more of a notary versus just having something between two people and then having to rely on those
people agreeing on on what happened kind of the idea that you why you want to decentralize solution in the first place
